item.title: Ninja Gaiden 4: Ryu Hayabusa Feels Like an Afterthought
item.description:
Don't shoot the messenger - I'm just saying, don't expect much from Ryu's playable story segments in Ninja Gaiden 4 . Over the past week or so, I've been able to play through and beat Ninja Gaiden 4 , and I'd say most of my expectations were topped by the flashy new action game. As Yakumo, it delivers everything I want from the combat and more, but PlatinumGames did confirm that there were two playable characters before release: newcomer Yakumo and veteran Ryu Hayabusa. I can easily point toward the worst gameplay segments in Ninja Gaiden 4 's story, and those are the ones where you play as Ryu.

But I do want to be clear: NG4 is a good game and, as a whole, I'd recommend it. I'd just recommend it with the caveat that your expectations for Ryu should be on the floor. Luckily, it is a relatively short segment of the game, taking up only a handful of chapters in Ninja Gaiden 4. It's worth noting that there's more to Ryu than just those chapters, at the very least, but it still feels like he's a side character in a franchise his name carries. SPOILER DISCUSSION FOLLOWS.

Spoilers for NG4 Ahead

Ryu's Role in the NG4 Story Explained

Without going further into spoiler territory than I have to, it becomes abundantly clear in the earliest hours of Ninja Gaiden 4 that Ryu truly is the "major challenge and growth milestone" for Yakumo that PlatinumGames suggested he'd be. Yakumo carries with him the arrogance and self-righteousness one would expect from a less-seasoned warrior, believing himself to be Ryu's equal from the beginning. The conflicts that emerge between the two are clearly one between a seasoned veteran and a prestigious upstart, and the story puts them at odds pretty quickly. There are several reasons for this, but as players progress through the story as Yakumo, they must complete four objectives. Throughout this, it is continuously suggested and then outright confirmed that the priestess Seori put those four objectives in placeâ€”with Ryu's help.

After spending the entire game clearing those four objectives, the playable segments for Ryu are flashbacks to setting up those four objectives. In other words, it's just repeating the content that's already been played. It surprises no gamer that each of those four objectives ends in a boss fight, and it's those very same boss fights for Ryu. Making it a little worse is that it goes backward, meaning the last objective that Yakumo finishes is the first one that Ryu set up. Players face one major boss back to back, first as Yakumo and then as Ryu, and then proceed to repeat levels to get to the other bosses. The one silver lining here is that each objective is shortened for Ryu, perhaps speaking to his power, but it's not like players need to be convinced that Ryu is the better ninja. Altogether, it's one of the shortest segments of the game, but the brevity, the repeated boss fights, and the fact that it has no real narrative bearing mean Ninja Gaiden 4 would have been better if these levels were cut .

Fans have been upset over Ryu's treatment in prior Ninja Gaiden games aren't likely to change their minds here.

How Cutting Playable Ryu Would Have Made Ninja Gaiden 4 Better

The pacing would be massively improved, for one. These flashbacks take place immediately following one of the biggest story beats in Ninja Gaiden 4 , interrupting the natural storytelling. Perhaps the goal is to create distance from that moment and what follows, which in and of itself is brief compared to the rest of the game, but it doesn't really accomplish that. It feels like repeated content shoved in between the resolution of the four objectives and the final boss. Secondly, it adds nothing to the gravitas of the story either. If there was something new revealed here, then perhaps playing through the content would have been worth it, but there's not. Seori's role in the four objectives is made clear early in the game, and it is implied throughout the game that Ryu was involved in it. The flashbacks serve no purpose narratively other than to explain maybe one detail, which is stretching the need for explanation.

Ninja Gaiden 4's Story Structure

  • Prologue and Set-Up
  • Complete Objective One
  • Complete Objective Two
  • Complete Objective Three
  • Complete Objective Four
  • Big Story Moment (Cutscene)
  • Repeat Objective Four, Three, Two, and One as Ryu
  • Final Chapters of the Game

Given that nothing of importance or anything new happens in Ryu's boss fights or story chapters, it feels very much like an afterthought shoved into the game for fan service. Now, there's absolutely nothing wrong with fan service, and having playable Ryu in Ninja Gaiden 4 only makes logical sense. But the fact remains, cutting his chapters would have made it a better game. Stepping into Ryu's shoes quickly goes from a surge of excitement to worries that everything feels very familiar to "Oh, so that's what we're doing. All of this. Again." The way the story unfolds, I would be more curious about what Ryu was doing during the rest of the present-day game instead of these flashbacks. The story and pacing would have been more interesting if each objective for Yakumo (which is roughly three chapters) was followed by an original present-day chapter for Ryu, instead of flashbacks.

Without that, outright cutting Ryu's chapters would have worked too, with his role as a playable character just being an endgame unlock. It already is, effectively, but his story chapters aren't necessary for that. As it stands, he feels like an arbitrary story reward instead of an actual one as players head into Ninja Gaiden 4 's higher difficulties/endgame content.

Ryu's Endgame Content in NG4

To reiterate, I liked and recommend playing Ninja Gaiden 4 . For me, it's a very good 8/10 game. I just think this part of the story hurts it overall and stops it from being a great or even amazing experience. The moment-to-moment combat is tons of fun, the content offerings are pretty good, and the overall story isn't revolutionary but is more than serviceable. I don't necessarily think more Ryu would have fixed it, but I wanted better Ryu content than flashbacks. Players, I'd argue, deserve more than the Super Ninja's main content being flashbacks.

However, once players get past those chapters and wrap up Ninja Gaiden 4 's story, Ryu can be picked as a playable character. Players can repeat chapters, do Purgatories, complete trials, and so on, which means at least there's more Ryu than in the story chapters. But for his playable story segments, it's hard not to be disappointed by how he's treated.

9 /10

Ninja Gaiden 4

item.title: Ninja Gaiden 4 Ending Explained
item.description:
This Article Contains MAJOR SPOILERS for Ninja Gaiden 4

Between 2015 and 2024, there were no brand-new Ninja Gaiden games to check out. That drought has ended with the releases of Ninja Gaiden 2 Black , Ninja Gaiden: Ragebound , and Ninja Gaiden 4 in 2025. Many fans are no doubt curious if these games, especially Ninja Gaiden 4 , ultimately signal the franchise's return to gaming prominence. The jury is still out on that, but in my mind, any new release is only as strong as its ending.

Ninja Gaiden 4 certainly has a well-defined ending to follow its excellent action gameplay. Overall, the story is not the main appeal of this game, but for lore fans, it introduces a lot to chew on. Spoilers begin with the next paragraph .

The Past in Ninja Gaiden 4

Ninja Gaiden 4 has a few flashback chapters near the end of the game, with these being the ones where beloved protagonist Ryu Hayabusa is playable, but for the sake of clarity, it's worth explaining this first. In the Ninja Gaiden 4 timeline, Ryu has killed the Dark Dragon twice, but these deaths are never permanent. Every time he kills it, it just comes back, so somewhere along the way, the decision was made to seal it in Tokyo. This splits the Dark Dragon into two: its body , which is visible throughout Tokyo, and its soul , which resides in the priestess Seori. The body creates a rotting rain around Tokyo, making it nigh unlivable except for the most hardened warriors and fiends.

The Archfiend Achilles used Seori to attempt a resurrection that Ryu thwarted. To ensure it cannot be revived, Ryu and Seori create elaborate seals spread throughout the world. At each of these seals, there is a sacred weapon that keeps the seal intact, and Ryu and Seori bind a daemon to the area to prevent anyone from breaking the seal. After that, it appears that Ryu and his ally Kagashi build and expand the power of the Divine Dragon Order (DDO), with one of those said seals existing at the top of its headquarters. Seori sets out to find some way to undo all the harm she has inadvertently caused by playing into Achilles' hand. Achilles is thought to be defeated at this time.

The Present in Ninja Gaiden 4

Years later, the present that begins in Ninja Gaiden 4 , Yakumo and a small crew of Raven Clan ninjas seek to break into the DDO's HQ, kill the Dark Dragon's priestess, and thus end theDark Dragon. This is because of a prophecy saying that a master ninja from the Raven Clan can kill the Dark Dragon for good.

The exact wording implies that, only after the priestess' death, a Raven Clan master ninja can "cleanse" the Dark Dragon. They believe Seori to be a captive of the DDO, but it seems more likely that she was just visiting as her relationship with Ryu is a good one, though players do not know this immediately. However, Seori stays Yakumo's hand by saying that they don't fully understand the prophecy and that they'd need her help to undo the seals to free the Dark Dragon (to cleanse/completely kill it once and for all).

The Raven Clan is a rival of the Hayabusa clan and has often been seen as second to them. This creates a certain grudge between the clans, as well as between Yakumo and Ryu.

From there, Yakumo, the Raven Clan, and Seori work to undo the four seals (that Seori and Ryu set up years prior). Yakumo spearheads everything, with everyone believing him to be the one capable of cleansing the Dark Dragon. Joining Yakumo and Seori are a few important figures:

  • Umi - A Comms Specialist
  • Tyran - Martial Arts Master
  • Misaki - The newest member of the Raven Clan and a trusted advisor

After agreeing to work with Seori, the players work through finding and undoing each of the Dark Dragon seals. Yakumo leads the way by clearing each area of fiends and enemies, supported by Tyran's training modules and Umi's communications. Misaki, meanwhile, escorts Seori to each location when it is safe. Along the way, there are a couple of important story beats:

  • Yakumo clashes with Ryu, with the latter and Ayane investigating Yakumo. This scene would imply that Ryu is attempting to save Seori and stop Yakumo from freeing the Dark Dragon.
  • Seori gets kidnapped by a Fiend, whom Yakumo must rescue. This sequence, especially, highlights a burgeoning relationship between Yakumo and Seori.

The Fourth Dark Dragon Seal

After breaking the first three Dark Dragon Seals, Yakumo and the party return to the DDO HQ for the last seal. Yakumo battles his way through, defeating Kagashi along the way, who is paraded as the most powerful member of the DDO (as also implied by his title). Along the way, players are treated to a cutscene of Seori speaking with Ryu, where she asks him to entrust Yakumo with a special item of the Dark Dragon if and only if Ryu deems him worthy. This cutscene is slightly confusing in terms of the timeline, but when it happens matters little. It could mean that she got away from Mizaki for a short time to talk with Ryu, or this could have happened when the party was in the DDO HQ at the start of the game. In the case of the latter, it means that Ryu has been fully informed and testing Yakumo the entire time. This would also explain why Ryu isn't hounding Yakumo throughout the journey.

Yakumo meets up with Mizaki and Seori at the final seal, and when Seori performs a ritual to expose the Dark Dragon's soul within her, she asks Yakumo to kill her. Yakumo hesitates, torn between his duty as a Raven Clan master ninja and as someone with feelings for Seori. Mizaki, instead, stabs Seori at this moment, revealing himself to actually be Achilles. This frees the Dark Dragon, with Yakumo fighting and killing Achilles in the immediate aftermath. Yakumo then takes Seori into his arms, as she talks about her mistakes and how she isn't really ready to die, and Yakumo cries while the Dark Dragon flies over Tokyo.

At this point in the game, players step into the shoes of Ryu, playing through flashbacks of him and Seori setting up the seals. When it returns to the present, Ryu rushes to the exit to the top of DDO HQ. The game then returns players to Yakumo's perspective.

Angered over the death of Seori, he rushes for that exit and faces Ryu one more time. The two engage in a battle, where Ryu deems Yakumo worthy. Ryu then gives Yakumo the final parting gift from Seori (the earlier cutscene)â€”the Jewel of the Dark Dragonâ€”which morphs into the Dark Dragon Blade. Part of the Dark Dragon itself, this Blade has the power to kill the Dark Dragon in the hands of a Raven Clan ninja because of their cursed bloodline.

The Dark Dragon's End in Ninja Gaiden 4

On the roof of DDO HQ, Yakumo faces the Dark Dragon and defeats it. The second phase of the boss battle sees the Dark Dragon take on Yakumo's form, which Yakumo defeats then too. Afterward, as the credits roll, players can run around Tokyo as it breathes fresh air for the first time in years, free from the poisonous effects of the Dark Dragon. Like Tokyo, Yakumo has freed himself and his clan from the curse of the bloodline by defeating the Dark Dragon. Without Ryu and Seori, he may not have had the skill to defeat the Dragon, but through their teachings (and loss in Seori's case), the world is a better place. Yakumo and Seori don't get a happy, romantic ending, but they achieve what they set out to do because of each other.

9 /10

Ninja Gaiden 4

item.title: Red Dead Redemption 2: Every Companion Item Request (& Where To Find Them)
item.description:
Rockstar's Red Dead Redemption 2 is massive, with the open-world game telling a story that stretches over 50 hours. The 2018 release takes its time to immerse players in the Old West, delivering a slow-paced adventure rich in personality and characters. As part of the Van der Linde gang, Arthur Morgan (and players) get to know each member intimately, and a charming part of this journey involves item requests . While these are optional, these quests flesh out the gang members, all the while emphasizing their bonds with Arthur.

RDR2 's companion camp requests require interacting with the characters during specific periods and then finding items from across the map, so completing them can be quite tricky and time-consuming. Furthermore, the game does not provide too much guidance, offering no markers to make discovering the items easy. Therefore, let's highlight when to initiate these quests and where to find the items in the world of Red Dead Redemption 2 .

Most companion item requests can only be triggered between 8 A.M. and 8 P.M. â€” this guide will state otherwise if that is not the case.

Updated on October 20, 2025, by Mark Sammut: At the moment, more than 40K people are playing Red Dead Redemption 2 on Steam. That is an insane number for a game that has been out for seven years. Sure, some people might be playing Red Dead Online, but the standalone version of that game averages about 1.5K players, so it doesn't seem to be absurdly popular. Consequently, there must be thousands of folks going through Arthur Morgan's journey right now. While that might seem strange for a single-player game, RDR2 is not only one of a kind but also regularly goes on sale for like $15, making it one of the best deals on Steam. It is an evergreen game by this point.

All the images have been either updated to a larger size or swapped out for a superior image.

Table of Contents for RDR2 Camp Requests

Red Dead Redemption 2 has 22 companion item requests, so there is quite a lot to go through. They start to become available in chapter 2, and they can be quite easy to miss if you are not paying attention. This article goes through all of RDR2 's item requests , and the following section includes links to each one. Just click on a companion to jump to their section.

Jump Links

  • Chapter 2 Item Requests
    • Abigail
    • Jack
    • Jack Request 2
    • Mary-Beth
    • Javier
    • Pearson
  • Chapter 2 or 3 Item Requests
    • Sean
  • Chapter 2, 3, or 4 Item Requests
    • Pearson
    • Bill
    • Charles
    • Charles Request 2
    • Hosea
    • Dutch
    • Susan
    • Lenny
  • Chapter 3 Item Requests
    • Tilly
    • Hosea
    • Molly
    • Kieran
  • Chapter 3 or 4 Item Requests
    • Sadie
  • Epilogue
    • Charles Request 3
  • Post-Game
    • Uncle

Abigail

Five Dollars

Chapter

2

Reward

-

One of the easiest of these little quests is found in Chapter 2. Abigail can be found in her tent, talking to Jack about his clothes. If players witness the discussion, they can give her five dollars to buy the kid a new outfit.

Abigail is the only character in the game who doesn't give players anything in return. However, the game itself rewards the nice gesture with an honor increase. It's also particularly easy because players shouldn't need to go anywhere to look for the item.

Jack

Penny Dreadful Comic Book

Chapter

2

Reward

Chocolate Bar

When going fishing with young Jack during the "A Fisher Of Men" mission , the kid laments that he left a book at their camp near Blackwater.

Players can find a replacement book at various locations. There's one in the School House situated in the abandoned settlement of Pleasance, just north of the 'O' in Lemoyne. When Arthur brings him the book, little Jack is so pleased that he gives the gunslinger a chocolate bar. Even if players just take on this task for the overwhelmingly wholesome result, this sidequest that shouldn't be overlooked.

Jack

Thimble

Chapter

2

Reward

A Picture

Jack also requests a second item, with the request triggered in Chapter 2. He comes up to Arthur at camp, worried that he's going to get in trouble for losing his mother's thimble. After the conversation, the player can find a new one by looting random bodies.

The likely blood-soaked thimble could be given to Jack in exchange for a piece of beautiful art â€” a picture the kid drew. Like Jack's other request, these are some of the sweetest item quests in the whole of Red Dead Redemption 2 .

Mary-Beth

Fountain Pen

Chapter

2

Reward

Gold Wedding Ring

Avid players will know Mary-Beth regularly writes in her journal while in camp. In Chapter 2, if the player interrupts her, she talks about her wish to use a fountain pen. The player can then get one by visiting Osman Grove in Roanoke Ridge , just southeast of Emerald Station.

To reward Arthur for getting a pen, Mary hands him a gold wedding ring, which sells at a decent amount. Tender moments like this, juxtaposed of course with bouts of intense violence, make the game the best Rockstar has ever released.

Javier

Oleander

Chapter

2

Reward

Poisoned Knives

Occasionally, Javier sits at the rectangular table in the Horseshoe Overlook camp, poisoning his knives. If Arthur then initiates a conversation, Javier will ask for some more oleander sage.

Players can pick up the plant from many areas, including the Riverbanks of Bayou Nwa . Javier uses the oleander to make more poisoned knives, some of which he gives to Arthur. The pair are certainly iconic cowboys in gaming when standing side by side.

Pearson

Naval Compass

Chapter

2

Reward

Guarma Rum

In the second chapter, between 8 A.M. and 2 P.M., Arthur can initiate a round of poker with his fellow gang members. During the game, Pearson might reveal that he's lost a compass he had in the Navy. Getting it back might sound complex, but it can be non-violent, so leave those extra-lethal melee weapons sheathed.

To get Pearson a replacement compass, players must go to the boathouse of the Braithwaite Manor. The new compass pleases Pearson so much that he gives Arthur some of his Guarma rum.

Sean

Kentucky Bourbon

Chapter

2 or 3

Reward

Firebombs

Between noon and 6 P.M. in either the second or third chapter, players can see Sean preparing firebombs in camp. After talking with the young man, he offers to make Arthur some, on the condition he brings him a bottle of bourbon.

It's one of the easiest item requests, as Kentucky bourbon is available in general stores, requiring just a little money and no violence. Head inside and use the game's astounding photo mode to see the inventory up close before buying a bottle. Sean keeps his word by crafting a few firebombs for the protagonist as a reward for the item.

Pearson

Rabbit

Chapter

2, 3, Or 4

Reward

Scout Jacket

For some reason, players have found Pearson's second item request really difficult to trigger. At some point, the cook is in camp preparing food while taking sips of his beer, between the hours of 8 A.M. and 12 P.M . Engage him in conversation, and he'll ask for a dead rabbit to cook.

Thankfully, fulfilling the item request is way easier than triggering it, as the woodland creatures can be hunted virtually anywhere on the map. Plus, the hunt is worth it as not only does it allow the cook to make a delicious stew , but he also gives Arthur a new scout jacket. Just keep it away from those glorious fire effects.

Bill

Hair Pomade

Chapter

2, 3, Or 4

Reward

High-velocity repeater/revolver rounds

This is another simple request that players can easily complete without any fuss. At some point in the second, third, or fourth chapter, Bill asks a surprised Arthur to get him some hair pomade. Players likely already have it, as it can be looted from almost anywhere. But if not, it can be bought from general stores.

There's some confusion surrounding the reward for this one, as some claim Arthur receives high-velocity repeater rounds for his trouble, whereas others get revolver ones. Either way, players end up with strong ammunition, powerful enough to open up one of gaming's best evil morality paths.

Charles

Moonshine

Chapter

2, 3, Or 4

Reward

Flaming Arrows

If players question Charles while he's crafting fire arrows in chapters 2-4, he'll promise to make a few for Arthur, provided he gets some more moonshine . Flaming arrows are a fun weapon to use in the heat of battle, if not a little messy, creating some of the best gang warfare in the gaming world.

Thankfully, moonshine is easy to procure, seeing as it's purchasable from fence shops. Upon returning with the item, Charles delivers on his promise by crafting a set of flaming arrows for his friend.

Charles

Oleander

Chapter

2, 3, Or 4

Reward

Poisonous Arrows

After completing the moonshine request, Arthur comes across Charles constructing poison arrows. And if players want some, they have to grab some oleander.

Players will know all about this one, presuming they've already helped Javier with his Oleander request. The riverbanks of Bayou Nwa are a good place to search for the poisonous plant. Once again, the good deed leads to Charles making some special arrows for Arthur, but this time there's a key difference: they're poisonous. These arrows are perfect for living the bandit fantasy in a video game and experimenting with new ways of killing enemies.

Hosea

The Case Of The Shrew In The Fog

Chapter

2, 3, Or 4

Reward

Predator Bait

Players initiate this item request by picking up a book titled "The Tale of The Deceitful German" near Hosea; it's found in camp. If Hosea sees you reading between the hours of 8A.M. and 8P.M., he'll ask for another book: The Case of the Shrew In The Fog . Arthur can then search for another book to give to his old friend.

It's located at a house in Hagen Orchards, right under the 'O' in Bayou Nwa, where players can find it on a coffee table. Clearly touched by the gesture, Hosea gives Arthur predator bait in return . Take it out hunting and enjoy some of the cinematic open-world experience while searching for prey.

Dutch

Pipe

Chapter

2, 3, Or 4

Reward

Set of Spurs

When Dutch is smoking a cigar outside of his tent, players can ask about it. In the proceding conversation, the charismatic leader says he prefers to smoke from pipes , so Arthur promises to get him one.

The pipe is found slightly Northeast of the 'W' in West Elizabeth , in a shack named Vetter's Echo â€” just watch out for the bear that lives there! After Arthur hands over the pipe, Dutch gives him a set of spurs. Although the open-world game has multiple endings, this particular interaction doesn't change Dutch's actions.

Susan

Herbs

Chapter

2, 3, Or 4

Reward

Miraculous Tonic

Susan will come to Arthur and request some seasoning herbs for Pearson's stew sometime between the second and fourth chapters. She'll accept two of either creeping thyme, oregano, or wild mint.

Some creeping thyme is outside of Valentine, around Citadel Rock. Picking herbs is one of the relaxing activities that lets Arthur reflect on life and the world around him, serving as a great reminder as to why the game has such incredible character development. The reward for fetching the herbs is a potent miracle tonic.

Lenny

Pocket Watch

Chapter

2, 3, Or 4

Reward

Dynamite

In a random campfire chat between 8 P.M. and 3 A.M ., Lenny tells a heartbreaking story about his father's missing pocket watch.

Luckily, Arthur can easily find a new one to give to the boy from any number of locations, including shacks, homesteads, and dead bodies. Odds are, a good round of third-person open-world shooting will yield at least one if the fight is substantial. It's an extremely personal and thoughtful gift to get for the young man. In return, Lenny offers Arthur some dynamite.

Tilly

Necklace

Chapter

3

Reward

Two Health Cures

A companion activity in Clemens Point involves playing Dominos with Tilly . During the game, she mentions how she's lost a necklace . As always, it's up to Arthur and the player to find her a new one. Places like gang hideouts, homesteads, and shacks tend to have jewelry to steal or loot.

Since Tilly is one of the more honorable gang members, it's no surprise that she thanks Arthur by giving him two health cures. If players notice screen tearing during this fetch quest, try improving the PC performance settings.

Hosea

American Ginseng

Chapter

3

Reward

Health Cure

From time to time in chapter 3, Hosea sits at the table in the middle of the camp and makes medicine. If players ask him about it, Hosea says he needs some more American ginseng , promising to brew Arthur some too.

One location where the plant grows is a little south of Cumberland Forest , overlooking the train tracks. With the right ingredients, he's able to manufacture a potent health cure for players. Missing out on this reward is one way the game punishes players for not doing the side content.

Molly

Pocket Mirror

Chapter

3

Reward

Cigar

The often-ignored Molly will approach Arthur in chapter 3 and talk about her broken mirror. Players can fetch a replacement for her at the homestead known as Martha's Swain. It's located directly east of Three Sisters in Ambarino , next to the train tracks.

As it's virtually the only time anyone is nice to the poor girl throughout the entire campaign, she's naturally pleased. So, she hands Arthur a cigar to show her appreciation. This scene might be short, yet it adds to a masterclass in cutscene direction.

Kieran

Burdock Root

Chapter

3

Reward

Horse Stimulant/Recipe for nutritious animal food

From noon to 6 P.M. at Clemens Point, Arthur can find Kieran grooming a horse. After greeting him, players discover that the horses need a bit of burdock root . It's a plant that can be found on the western side of the great plains, particularly near riverbeds - two of them are needed for this quest. Arthur can easily forage around this area to find it.

Kieran further proves his love of horses with his reward, as it's not really a gift for players but one for their steeds. It's a horse stimulant and a pamphlet explaining how to make a nutritious meal for the animal. Admire the impressive graphics in the game while feeding the horse along a scenic path.

Sadie

Harmonica

Chapter

3 Or 4

Reward

Gun Oil

During the "Further Questions of Female Suffrage" mission, Sadie will mention how she used to play the harmonica. She lost the instrument, but players can fetch her a new one at Granger's Hoggery.

The location is just east of Flatneck Station and a little north of Flat Iron Lake. Arthur's retrieval efforts are rewarded with some gun oil, which is very appropriate for Sadie. It's good to take care of this quest as soon as possible, because the reward provdes useful throughout the rest of the game, preserving and protecting all Arthur's guns.

Charles

Eagle Feather

Chapter

Epilogue Part 2

Reward

Horse Revived

In part 2 of the epilogue, Charles starts hammering nails into the newly built barn. Interacting with him will lead to a discussion about the eagle feather he keeps with him. Players must then bring him another one.

Eagles are virtually everywhere in West Elizabeth, but a good spot to find them nearby is around the Lower Montana River going into the Aurora Basin. As thanks, Charles hands over a horse reviver. The moment is a nice break in an otherwise stressful open-world game.

Uncle

Home Remedy Ingredients

Chapter

Post-Game

Reward

Four Clothing Items

Sometime after the game's final mission, Uncle will come up and ask the player for a bunch of ingredients for a home remedy. The Kentucky bourbon and hair pomade are available to buy at general stores, whereas the peppermint is purchasable from any stables.

As for the Milkweed , it grows around river banks in Lemoyne, for example, Dewberry Creek.

The last ingredient is the skunk , which players can hunt almost anywhere, with Tall Trees being the closest area. This request takes more work than most, with quite a few items required to complete it, so players are entitled to a decent reward. Well, it's certainly a hefty one, as John receives four items of clothing: tornado boots, a classic frock coat, a drifter hat, and a frontier vest. For those hoping for a combat boost, download a fantastic weapon mod.

Are Red Dead Redemption 2's Item Requests Worth Doing?

Red Dead Redemption 2 is an extremely long game that is packed to the brim with content, especially optional content that can be readily missed. If you are not going for a complete playthrough, you might start taking into consideration what side content is worth doing, or if it might be better to ignore most of that stuff and primarily focus on the main storyline. The camp item requests are, admittedly, quite easy to overlook since they are ultimately minor parts of the overall journey, and skipping them will not detract all that much from the experience. Conversely, they are not particularly difficult or time-consuming to complete, although triggering some of the requests can be surprisingly challenging.

Honestly, if we are talking solely in terms of rewards, these quests are mostly not worth the effort. Pearson's Scout Jacket is pretty neat and probably the best of the bunch, but it is hardly a must-own item that makes a difference in the grand scheme of things. However, RDR2 's strongest feature is its writing and characters, two things that are arguably enhanced by the item requests. Completing these missions can help strengthen the bond you, the player, feel with Arthur's companions, and the interactions are generally quite charming and enjoyable.

Ultimately, the best approach might be to not seek out these moments, but also to embrace them when they come around. Throughout a playthrough, there should be situations when you naturally find yourself at a camp at the right time for an item request, and you should just go ahead and complete it.
